Participatory Research in Geography: Techniques

Work in Public Participatory GIS (PPGIS) and Participatory GIS (PGIS) has for many years emphasized the need for deep community engagement as an aspect of quantitative spatial analysis. The incrasing ubiquity of big data, volunteered geographic informaiton (VGI), open data and software and mobile and web based IGS sytems has significantly shaped these efforts, allowing for new forms of collaboration and community based data collection. With increased use of VGI data from social media and similiar sources, however, non-academics may also become increasingly marginalized within the research process.

In this session, we discuss the future of participatory spatial analysis, one that creatively makes use of new and emerging forms of data collection, analysis, and distribution or finds new uses for traditional methods. Presenters are engaged in work that substantively engages with groups outside the academy--local/regional governments, non-profits, neighborhood organizations, or other similar actors.

Organizers: Jerry Shannon, Ian Rossiter, Dorris Scott

Chair: Ian Rossiter

Participants:
Presenter: Jake Wade, Building Data from the Ground Up for FLooding and Disaster Management in Hopkins, Belize
Co-Presenter: Amanda Ashby
Presenter: Jerry Shannon, Smart Maps for Small Cities: Visualizing Housing Conditions with Open Source Tools
Presenter: Heather Fischer, Tourist-Volunteered Geographic Information
Presenter: Hannah Kay Bonestroo, Understanding Coastal Marine Debris Through Participatory Geographic Information Systems
Co-Presenter: Saraneh Fitzgerald
Presenter: Donald Lafreniere, Empowering Heritage Preservation, Environmental Policy and GIS Education through Historical PPGIS and Mobile Big Data

Sponsorships: Environmental Perception and Behavioral Geography Specialty Group

Participatory Research in Geography: Approaches

Work in Public Participatory GIS (PPGIS) and Participatory GIS (PGIS) has for many years emphasized the need for deep community engagement as an aspect of quantitative spatial analysis. The incrasing ubiquity of big data, volunteered geographic informaiton (VGI), open data and software and mobile and web based IGS sytems has significantly shaped these efforts, allowing for new forms of collaboration and community based data collection. With increased use of VGI data from social media and similiar sources, however, non-academics may also become increasingly marginalized within the research process.

In this session, we discuss the future of participatory spatial analysis, one that creatively makes use of new and emerging forms of data collection, analysis, and distribution or finds new uses for traditional methods. Presenters are engaged in work that substantively engages with groups outside the academy--local/regional governments, non-profits, neighborhood organizations, or other similar actors.

Organizers: Jerry Shannon, Dorris Scott, Ian Rossiter

Chair: Dorris Scott

Participants:
Presenter: Colleen Hammelman, Affective methos in community-based participatory research
Presenter: Nehal El-Hadi, The Planner and the Online Archive
Presenter: Daniel R. Block, Varying Levels of Public Participation in PPGIS: Lessons and Examples from Chicago
Presenter: Patricia A. Solis, Building mappers not just maps: challenges and opportunities from YouthMappers on scaling up the crowd in crowd-sourced open mapping for development

Map Jam I

  • • network with community organizers and students
  • • learn how to foster your own local OpenStreetMap community

Participatory Research in Geography: Disaster

The popularity and prevalence of mobile devices have brought seemingly endless opportunities to deliver and collect location-based information to a mobile population. This paradigm shift has brought new opportunities to improve and build upon efforts related to Public Participation Geographic Information Systems (PPGIS) research and applications. Challenges posed by disasters are one such problem that could benefit from improved PPGIS. There are multiple phases of disaster including mitigation, preparedness, response, recovery, and resilience. Each phase requires different data, inviting citizen engagement within a participatory GIS. Multiple parties rely on data related to disasters to help to prepare and respond to an event. These parties include individuals from the community, private sector, government agencies, and researchers. Each actor has informational or data needs when passing through various phases of a disaster. Mobile devices and distributed systems present opportunities to collect relevant disaster data in which citizen (could) share their local knowledge in through PPGIS initiatives. Papers presented in this session cover topics pertaining to PPGIS data collection and disaster.

Organizers: Britta Ricker, Gretchen Fagg, Michelle Montgomery Thompson

Chair: Britta Ricker

Participants:
Presenter: Gretchen Fagg, Participatory Geographies, Partnerships & Preparedness: Exploring community engagement, collaboration, and co-design of disaster preparedness tools
Presenter: Jeroen Verplanke, "We've arrived at the shelter!" Assessing Flood Evacuation Information from Twitter. Case Study: Jakarta
Presenter: Michelle Montgomery Thompson, Moving History: Place-based Planning for Affordable Housing in New Orleans
Presenter: Ana Brandusescu, Local participation in crowdmapping chronic disasters
Discussant: Britta Ricker

Participatory Research in Geography: Expectations, Expertise, and Engagement

Past work in critical pedagogy, participatory action research, and political ecology has emphasized the need for research that draws upon and develops existing expertise within communities, critiquing top down models rooted in researchers' own questions, expertise, and positionalities. In practice, however, community groups often look to academics for guidance for both the tchincal aspects of research design and the best ways to frame and interpret research results. With limited time and fincancial resources, groups may expect academics to take charge, providing structure and direction that expedites the research process. This panel session will focus on a discussion of how to navigate community expectations, the role of researchers' own expertise, and a commitment to participatory research. Questions that shape the discussion include:
In what ways do you provide theoretical or methodological input to the communities you work with, and what factors shape the ways you do so?
What kinds of "expertise" do they hope you can provide? How have you responded to those requests?
Communities may look to academics for both substantive expertise--knowledge about a particular issue or experience working within certain theoretical frameworks--or for technical asistnace with research design and implementation. As a researcher, are you more inlicned to provide input with one of these over the other?
How does your own insider/outsider status (with regards to race/class/gender/regional/etc. identities) with communities shape the kinds of input you feel comfortable providing or the ways you speak with/for them?
Can you share a time you now wish you had played a more active role at shaping a community research project--when your perspective or experience could have been helpful? Or conversely, a time when you now think you were too active?

Organizers: Jerry Shannon, Katherine B. Hankins, Andy Walter

Chair: Jerry Shannon

Participants:
Panelist: Katherine B. Hankins
Panelist: Richard Milligan
Panelist: Daniel R. Block
Panelist: Renee Sieber
Panelist: Tracey Osborne
Panelist: Jonnell A. Robinson

OpenStreetMap in Research, Education, and Applied Projects

OpenStreetMap (OSM) is the most widely used open geospatial database that is based on volunteered geographic information (VGI). OSM's success and worldwide content attracts a range of different public, private sector and governmental actors. Many projects focus on the humanitarian and development community, environmental and transportation sector, environmental justice, community mapping, and international education. The OSM platform serves successfully as a link between the activities and interests of the academic community, NGOs, private sector, along with public needs. This paper session is part of a set of activities under the banner of the 2017 Mapathon@AAG event, co-organized by MapGive, an initiative of the U.S. Department of State, YouthMappers, a program supported by the U.S. Agency for International Development, and George Mason University. OSM has grown over the past 10 years and the resulting open, crowdsourced database has been utilized in many projects and applications. Thus this session will facilitate a scientific discussion between researchers and practitioners that are actively involved in OSM activities.

Organizers: Patricia A. Solís, Sven Fuhrmann

Chair: Sven Fuhrmann

Participants:
Presenter: Cynthia Ann Brewer, Incorporating OpenStreetMap Data in Penn State's Online Campus Map
Presenter: Jennings Anderson, Contributor-Centric OpenStreetMap Research
Presenter: Tricie Coulter Mauray, How to Reach the World from One Campus: A Case Study on the Use of OpenStreetMap by an Interdisciplinary Student Organization
Presenter: Daisy Tam, HKFoodWorks: Crowd-Sourcing Food Rescue in Hong Kong
Presenter: Weihe Wendy Guan, Harvard Hypermap: An Open Source Framework for Making the World's Geospatial Information more Accessible

Information geographies: Social dimensions of Web 2.0 I

For about a decade, geographers have reflected on new forms of online cartographies, assessing their nature, scope and impacts through terms like "volunteered geographic information" (VGI), "neogeography," "new spatial media", or "web 2.0 cartographies."
Much of this literature deals with the broader implications of web 2.0 cartographies for society and is often linked to constructivist and normative approaches from critical, participatory or feminist GIS. Generally, this kind of research investigates the risks and potentials of VGI and user-generated online maps for the greater goals of justice, equality and democracy.
Meanwhile, web 2.0 cartographies have ceased to be something new. The once revolutionary collaborative mapping platforms OpenStreetMap and Wikimapia, as well as the triumphant incursion of a technology called the "map mashup" have long passed their tenth anniversaries. Today, interactive maps have become a standard feature of user's online experiences. Contemporary "neo"-geographers have at their disposal a diverse range of APIs, script libraries and data repositories, enabling them to create beautiful maps for all kinds of purposes.
Yet, it is exactly the prevalence and mainstreaming of web 2.0-cartographies which demands an ongoing investigation of their societal imprints and implications, which have not been satisfyingly explored so far.
In this session, we have invited papers discussing any of the following:
  • - Characteristics and motivations of contributors to crowdsourced web maps such as OpenStreetMap, Google Map Maker, and Wikimapia
  • - Studies of the political economy surrounding the online production of VGI, including corporate influence in maintaining or supporting VGI platforms
  • - Effects of Web 2.0 cartographies on human perceptions of the landscape
  • - Critical analysis of cartographic selection, classification, and symbolization in Web 2.0 maps
  • - Critical code studies investigating the anatomy and genesis of web maps
  • - Innovative uses of VGI or Web 2.0 maps for social or environmental justice efforts
  • - Impacts and embeddedness of collaborative web maps in political debates and conflicts
  • - Questions of nation state sovereignty vis à vis user-generated geodata beyond the jurisdictional access of authorities
  • - Postcolonial perspectives on reproductions of power relations and inequalities through web cartographies

Organizers: Sterling Quinn - Central Washington University , Christian Bittner

Chair: Sterling Quinn - Central Washington University

Participants:
Presenter: Laura Garcia - University of Ottawa , Are individuals responsible for their own privacy in the geoweb: A jurispudence analysis.
Presenter: Stefano De Sabbata - University of Leicester Pengyuan Liu - University of Leicester, Exploring Information Geographies through Data Mining
Presenter: Lea Bauer - Leibniz Institute for Regional Geography , Tactical maptivism. A methodical approach to understand counter-mapping practices as a political tactic.
Presenter: Sterling Quinn - Central Washington University Doran Tucker - The Pennsylvania State University, Geopolitical conflict and elusive ground truth in online maps

Information Geographies: Data, democracy, and improving the world with critical VGI

In the 10 years since Goodchild (2007) coined the term "Volunteered Geographic Information" (VGI) geographers have studied quality (Senaratne et al., 2016) , as well as the inequalities created by uneven participation (Graham, 2009, Stephens, 2013, Graham et al., 2015), and the negative impacts of the geoweb on communities (Crutcher and Zook, 2009; Elwood and Leszczynski, 2008). We want to understand the benefits VGI to society and give tools for volunteers, activists, and scholars to continue in this field without reproducing inequality or further marginalizing populations. Specifically we will ask our panelists the following:
  • -Can VGI be used to improve human conditions in terms of community engagement, neo-colonial research, the global south, gentrification, race, gender, integration of new ideas and new populations?
  • -Can VGI move beyond the current impact of issues related to community engagement, neo-colonial research, the global south, gentrification, race, gender, integration of new ideas and new populations?
  • -How can we promote widening participation in who produces VGI?
  • -How can we operationalize a critique that improves research on VGI?
  • -How can a critique lead to engaging with VGI communities, identifying neglected areas based on quantitative and qualitative analysis?
  • -Can visual analytics be an effective tool for VGI communities to explore their information inequalities, and promote wider participation and further content creation?
  • -Can VGI and open-source GIS offer alternative, non-cartesian understanding of space, that could enable the representation of different perspectives?
  • -What software and tools should we develop to enable diverse conceptions of space, time, place, landscape and nature to be representable?
  • We are additionally interested in using geographic data to understand activism and resistance to xenophobia at a time when Brexit, Donald Trump, and #alllivesmatter, dominate the news.

Organizers: Monica G. Stephens - University At Buffalo, Stefano De Sabbata - University of Leicester

Chair: Monica G. Stephens - University At Buffalo

Introduction: Stefano De Sabbata - University of Leicester, Monica G. Stephens - University At Buffalo

Panelists:
Taylor Shelton - University of Kentucky
Catherine D'Ignazio - Emerson College
Kate Chapman
Susan Wolfinbarger - American Association for the Advancement of Science

Discussants:
Agnieszka Leszczynski - University of Auckland
Dorothea Johanna KLEINE - University of Sheffield

Information geographies: Social dimensions of Web 2.0 cartographies II

For about a decade, geographers have reflected on new forms of online cartographies, assessing their nature, scope and impacts through terms like "volunteered geographic information" (VGI), "neogeography," "new spatial media", or "web 2.0 cartographies."
Much of this literature deals with the broader implications of web 2.0 cartographies for society and is often linked to constructivist and normative approaches from critical, participatory or feminist GIS. Generally, this kind of research investigates the risks and potentials of VGI and user-generated online maps for the greater goals of justice, equality and democracy.
Meanwhile, web 2.0 cartographies have ceased to be something new. The once revolutionary collaborative mapping platforms OpenStreetMap and Wikimapia, as well as the triumphant incursion of a technology called the "map mashup" have long passed their tenth anniversaries. Today, interactive maps have become a standard feature of user's online experiences. Contemporary "neo"-geographers have at their disposal a diverse range of APIs, script libraries and data repositories, enabling them to create beautiful maps for all kinds of purposes.
Yet, it is exactly the prevalence and mainstreaming of web 2.0-cartographies which demands an ongoing investigation of their societal imprints and implications, which have not been satisfyingly explored so far.
In this session, we have invited papers discussing any of the following:
  • - Characteristics and motivations of contributors to crowdsourced web maps such as OpenStreetMap, Google Map Maker, and Wikimapia
  • - Studies of the political economy surrounding the online production of VGI, including corporate influence in maintaining or supporting VGI platforms
  • - Effects of Web 2.0 cartographies on human perceptions of the landscape
  • - Critical analysis of cartographic selection, classification, and symbolization in Web 2.0 maps
  • - Critical code studies investigating the anatomy and genesis of web maps
  • - Innovative uses of VGI or Web 2.0 maps for social or environmental justice efforts
  • - Impacts and embeddedness of collaborative web maps in political debates and conflicts
  • - Questions of nation state sovereignty vis à vis user-generated geodata beyond the jurisdictional access of authorities
  • - Postcolonial perspectives on reproductions of power relations and inequalities through web cartographies

Chair: Christian Bittner

Visualizing for Justice - Creative, Critical and Contestational Mapping

A public event on data visualization and mapping for social justice in association with the American Association of Geographers subconference.

The rise of Big Data, freedom of information and user-friendly software has contributed to the popularity of infographics, data visualizations and mapping for civic engagement and advocacy. This surge in data visualization brings with it opportunities for information re-use, increased transparency, and new forms of civic participation. Yet visualizing data for social justice also comes with its own set of challenges​. From issues of security and tracking down hard to find information, to the ethics of making infographics out of death and suffering, participatory practices of data visualization often take place on ambiguous ethical terrain.

Wednesday, April 5
6:00pm - 10:00pm
The Bordy Theater at Emerson College 216 Tremont Street Boston, 02116

RSVP on EventBrite

Secondary Cities: Mapping Human Geography Data

This session will focus on the US Office of the Geographer and Global Issues signature initiative -- Secondary Cities. Secondary Cities is in the second year expanding into new cities that are under-examined and under-mapped. The fundamental aim of these projects is to identify critical data needs, utilize open source tools, and create robust datasets for sustainable futures. This session will provide an overview of Secondary Cities, describe a case study, and present methods for remote and local mapping of Secondary Cities.

Organizers: Melinda J. Laituri - Colorado State University

Chair:Melinda J. Laituri - Colorado State University

Participants:
Dmytro Saltovets - SpaeroGIS
Oleksandr Popov - Kharkiv City Council
Sergei Dovzhenko
Svitlana Dudenko
Candice Luebbering - American Association of Geographers

Resources for Expanding Open Geospatial Education

The goal of this session is to form discussion around open geospatial education, and eliminating barriers including high monetary costs, outdated or obsolete materials, and legal mechanisms that prevent collaboration among scholars and educators. This session will feature a panel of speakers whom believe everyone in the world should have access to high-quality educational experiences and resources, and are active in the open geospatial education community. The panel will highlight currently available educational resources, and determine areas where additional resources are needed.

Organizers: Anthony Calamito - Boundless

Chair:Anthony Calamito - Boundless

Participants:
Dmytro Saltovets - SpaeroGIS
Oleksandr Popov - Kharkiv City Council
Sergei Dovzhenko
Svitlana Dudenko
Candice Luebbering - American Association of Geographers

The 2nd Mapathon @ AAG

April 6–8, Boston

Join us for a three day Mapathon and contribute to OpenStreetMap for humanitarian efforts during the AAG Conference

This is the 2nd year that Mapathons and Mapathon related activities will be hosted at AAG. Conference attendees can join a community of online mappers and contribute to OpenStreetMap for humanitarian efforts. Using satellite imagery and freely available OpenStreetMap editing platforms, participants will trace, edit, and label key infrastructure (buildings, roads, etc.), environmental features, and other objects for the creation of openly available real data to produce maps that assist humanitarian and community efforts.

The Mapathon events will feature a wide array of impactful speakers from academia, government, and the private sector. The first Mapathon on Friday afternoon will be hosted on the MIT campus, with mapping projects supporting the Presidential Emergency Plan for Aids Relief (PEPFAR). The Mapathon on Saturday afternoon will be held in the AAG Mapathon lounge and will feature select mapping projects in South America. All Mapathon events are open to the public, you just need to RSVP.

The Mapathons will promote themes of shared humanitarian interest, and mapping will be coordinated through the Humanitarian OpenStreetMap Team’s Tasking Manager. Recognizing the power that Mapathons have to educate, engage, and empower the public, the organizers hope that at the end of the conference, participants will have made significant contributions towards improved maps to support humanitarian response and sustainable development efforts. For more information about the Mapathons and related AAG activities, please e-mail MapGive@state.gov.

The core organizers of the Mapathon @ AAG include the U.S. Department of State's Office of the Geographer and Global Issues, USAID's GeoCenter, and George Mason University's Department of Geography and GeoInformation Science.

AAG Conference Code of Conduct: Professional ideas and information are exchanged most effectively at the AAG Annual Meeting in an atmosphere free of abuse or harassment and characterized by courtesy and respect. To that end, the AAG expects all individuals who attend to conduct themselves in a manner that establishes an atmosphere free from discriminatory practices.
